comments.body:
I really like this idea. I really do. I have said to myself that bigger and better dungeons would be a major step up to the dungeons we have today. But, these dungeons would have to be a little bit harder than whet you've put in here. I don't think 4-8 spawners is going to cut it. If we are talking about loot, like tools, diamonds and enchantment books, then having more spawners will make the dungeons more balanced.

For Example:
1) You don't want to have a dungeon that just lets players walk inside and take all of the loot. That would be a heavy unbalance to the game.
2) The dungeons rarity would have to be quite low, as having them spawn at the rate of ravines would make them to easy to find.
3) If these dungeons are able to spawn in the Nether/End, they are going to have to have more loot and more enemies, or finding them just wouldn't be worth it.
4) If we are talking about dungeons that can have different features depending on what biome they're in, that means that they may have to have items and loot based around that biome.
5) Going back to the rarity thing, bigger dungeons might be better off if they are more rare.

Just to remind you, I do really like this idea, and in total, I don't see many problems with it. There aren't any major problems with this idea. Plus, Minecraft is heavily overdue for these types of ideas.

If you add even more spawners, the dungeon would be a dungeon and the ultimate natural mob farm once you've cleared it.  Even as it stands, I would be beating it for the close proximity of multiple spawners more than anything that you could find in the chests.

Given the number of diamonds and enchanted books I've found in easy to raid chests, I don't think the loot is too much.

Another thing to keep in mind is in Bedrock, mobs from spawners never despawn.  So clearing one of these wouldn't be like Java where you find it, back off to make everything despawn, and then rush in with torches.  Unless you managed to notice it from a distance, you're going to be dealing with a built up group of mobs that you have to kill to make the area safe.

Gotta agree with ClayGoddessSari here. More crazy mob spawners just means more crazy mob farming once you've defeated the whole thing. I don't think that's a consequence the Mojang devs would particularly like.

I put this idea is as a placeholder and for a few comments to roll in. I have considered that once you clear it you can use the spawners, I did that for a reason. Not just for the items, but because the mob kinds can vary, like endermen and skeletons. It would be like a hidden bonus for clearing it. Also, notice how I said dungeon, not STRONHOLDS, which are much bigger compared to a dungeon.

I think instead of a cube temple it should be modeled after a mayan temple or something like that with more traps and hidden passages. The same could be said about the desert pyramid.
IMO, it'd be cool if the dungeons had designs similar to the first Zelda and the gameboy titles.

I created a post to tie into the better dungeon post. These will slightly nerf the dungeon's mob spawning abilities. I hope this may clear up your concern s about the mobfarms ClayGoddessSari and MachuPichu.

Dungeons need an upgrade. But, that is for a cave update. I will only talk about what should be added to the dungeons.   1: They should be bigger. A 7x7 area doesn't live up to it's name. We could improve that by giving them a big, random shape, when you enter, there will be 3-5 spawners with zombies, skeletons, or spiders. Later on you will find redstone dispensers, and a new mob, the guardian. 3 blocks tall, 1.5 blocks wide, and 1 block long. They would be heavily armored, with the mercenary armor from minecraft dungeons, with a small improvement. They would wield a battleaxe and guard the treasure room. It would have diamonds, gold, iron, emeralds, and 0-3 netherite scraps. And normal dungeon/desert temple/ mineshaft loot. That's all i have to say about the dungeons in minecraft.

I would love to see a dungeon that you actually get to explore and isn't only a little square room. Imaginé traversing it and getting lost in the underground halls fighting mobs, avoiding traps, and perhaps even (though I know this might be pushing it) fighting a mini-boss of sorts (like the Elder Guardian in Ocean Monumentos).
I would say the dungeon would be too big, I would probably have it around slightly longer than a normal dungeon and slightly slimmer

I agree some new challenge would be good, and another post got me thinking of "Pocket Dimensions" for Mazes and Dungeons, this would allow for huge/detailed builds without impacting the world generation, just an archway for the portal. To decrease the Mob Farm have these pocket dimensions be more like events, lasting only about 4 hours real-time (12 game days) and then they close and regenerate. On Peaceful and Normal a player trapped inside would be teleported to the archway, Hard and Hardcore would fall to void, items stored in chests in the dungeon would be lost. Every game day a gong/alarm would do the count down from 12 rings. So if you only hear 1 gong in the dungeon you have 20 minutes to escape. This would allow for mixing blocks/mobs from all dimensions, so you never know your loot, or danger you will face in what combination. As an optional risk/reward with no ability to farm and a limited time frame, I think would add playability. Especially if they even only start randomly every few full moons.

Also, maybe add (at some point) basically a mega dungeon with tons of great loot, but tons of mobs. Like maybe it goes by a floor system that gets harder as you go down, thus better loot with the bottom layer having something insane like netherite but maybe a new boss to guard it or just an insane amount of spawners.
Dungeons certainly should have a varying number of rooms and maybe stairs and trapdoors.
What if the structures used dispensers with spawn eggs for the mobs? This avoids the spawner problem and would make for interesting survival collectibles if you can stop the mechanism early enough.

If mob farms are a concern with putting more spawners in a dungeon, then perhaps some of them could spawn stronger mobs (e.g. wearing armor or having beneficial status effects) or even spawn mobs unique to dungeons.

They're pretty rare to come across, but most of the time there's really never much incentive to go to one since there isn't really much there of value. Maybe some sort of item or variants of pre-existing items that change depending on what biome the abandoned village is in & tells a little more story as to maybe why the village was abandoned in the first place.
The idea of Villagers trying to interact with Archaeology's features is interesting, but this specific proposition isn't.

The most important thing is that the found items should depend on the type of house and its inhabitants.
- In the seedbeds you can find tools and/or rare plant seeds.
- Under the foundations of the church there are bottles, potions, blaze rods, etc.
- Under the smith's shop there will be armor, swords, etc.

Also for regular villages you can add 1-2 abandoned houses where you can do excavations. You can also add a Well at the bottom of which will be a variety of things that were accidentally dropped.
The well can be either in a residential or in an abandoned village *

Another option is another abandoned village, whose foundations are completely or partially underground. Only small pieces of walls will stick out of it, thanks to which you can find this village. The player will have to remove the earth, open up the floor and start excavating to find out what happened.
Very cool. It will be much more interesting to look for these abandoned villages

(Copy and Paste this in Desp!!!) As of the recent snapshot archeology can only be done around the desert wells and desert temples. Similar to the smithing templates, archeology should be done around different structures too. We would need a ancient structure though, and the two structures which could be classified "ancient" are the Jungle Temples and Ocean Ruins. You would need to add more than just suspicious sand though, because random blocks of sand wouldn't look all to well with dirt and gravel. A solution would be to add suspicious dirt and suspicious gravel and then sprinkle them around the ancient structures. With these new blocks we can have pottery shards uniqe to the structure making pots more customizable. The last thing I have in mind is ancient villages. These villages would be the remains of the ancient builders villages in which they lived in many hundreds of years ago. With a structure like ancient villages they could be havens for archeology. with suspicious gravel, dirt, and sand everywhere along with ruined and buried stone and mud houses. unqi or all shards could be found here. As your digging you can dig up the story of what happened there and why they were ruined or abandoned. Along with brushing, you could find buried houses and rooms with loot inside and possible treasure maps and structure maps to mineshafts, temples, strongholds and more. With the ruined houses, there could be a in game reference on how to make golems similar to the ruined portal.

I agree, I would also like to add that other than blazes there should an items/mobs that only spawn in nether fortresses. This would give players a reason to go explore and find the nether fortresses.

Here are a few ideas I came up with

Nether star shard- Littered throughout nether fortresses are star holder (empty beacons with a shard). The player would have to fight a star guardian which is a brand of wither skeletons with armor. They would drop keys to open the holders. Put four nether star shards in a crafting table and get a formed nether star.

Chains- Nether fortresses would have hanging chains. The player can use these chains in crafting chain-mail armor, or just use them for decoration.

Sulfur pools- Toxic to the touch they spawn as falling traps for those unlucky explores who fall. You can bucket the sulfur for a short time before it breaks the bucket. Only gold buckets can pick up sulfur. A bucket of sulfur can be used to increase how much smelting can be done. One bucket of sulfur allows 3 stacks of items to smelt in one given moment. Buckets of sulfur when they hit water evaporates the water. When sulfur hits lava, the sulfur would disappear.

Absolutely. Nether fortresses are outdated and need an overhaul. Perhaps Mojang could incorporate some forms of visually distinct mob zones, kind of like different wings to the fortresses. Wither skeleton areas, complete with withering nether bricks, Blaze areas with melted floors, walls, etc, Piglin bastions which are generally tribal-looking. The current nether fortress design and aesthetic doesn't fit in with the style of mobs now prevalent in the Nether.

Also, the Casual Friday 20w07a stream came off as kind of pompous and condescending. Fans obviously want more content than just mobs and some tiny biomes. This is the "Nether Update". Make it grand. Have the Nether be more than just a weird progression stepping stone. Actually make the dimension complex, interesting, and able to rival the Overworld as a viable option for long term play.

I don't think this large amount of coal would be unfair considering the nether is full of lava and lava does the same things that coal does. (Fuel and lighting.) With all the new blocks and features being added to the game, I believe that the nether fortress has great potential.

Edit: Wow! I love the new biome added to Minecraft in a snapshot (The basalt delta). Maybe this dark variant of the nether fortress I mentioned could be made from Blackstone instead of coal... Surely would look better. I'd also love to see some Blackstone included in the design of the normal nether fortress. I also wanted to add that I love how much detail the village houses got in 1.14 and I kinda expect to see similar amounts of detail in the nether fortress if it were to get updated. Minescrafter02 has a good idea about the layout of the nether fortress but there is a problem. Structurally it looks good, but the main problem is most of the structure still used the brown nether brick. While the original fortress used the same color nether brick, we as community should add a bit more color to the build. We could keep the railings brown nether brick but allow the walkway below it to be a different color.

 

Something like this for example.

 

 

When you look at these stairs you tell straight right away there is a bit more color added to the original build. Sure its tiny but I kind of wanted to keep some of the original nether brown bricks for the sides while making the pathway up a bit different. This gives off a bit of a creepy vibe to it as you are about to enter the warped forest version of the fortress. Another example would be inside the room itself.

Its a bit dark inside but you can easily tell there is a bit of difference in the layout of this area. The blue glass might not work as well but you can get a sense of the difference. Its a bit of an improvement over single brown nether brick. A good nether fortress shouldn't be all blue, or all red, or all brown but using a variety of different colors that complements the region itself.

The big question is what should the new nether fortress look like?
I have to admit, these pictures are beautiful. I would love some more colors to the nether fortresses.

I had a post rejected for I assume to be its similarity to yours, so I will instead comment here:

Nether fortresses in the Soul Sand Valley should be made of black nether brick / basalt bricks as it fits the aesthetic of the biome better and adds a block that a lot of players have been wanting.

Material should be based off of the biome the nether fortress began to generate in to prevent jarring changes, so if a fortress spawns in the nether wastes and extends into a soul sand valley, it will continue to be made of normal nether bricks.

Black nether bricks could also be crafted using nether bricks and basalt or soul sand. I would personally advise against black dye as it puts forward the idea of all 16 nether brick colours, which is not the aim of this suggestion.

I would like to share my idea about updating The Nether Fortress.

I think that right now is a perfect time for changing The Fortress because of The Nether Update. My idea is about changing the base structure of the dungeon (or to have various structural designs) and to have some kind of a goal for your need to be there (like: to get an item/s in order to craft something, achieve an achievement and so on). To be introduced a new mob/s like Nether Guards (It just got in my head about the name, haha) and to be obtained something from them (netherite ore, potions, piece of armor) and also maybe to add new blocks which are obtainable only from this dungeon. For my last thing for the list of new things: to have some kind of an underground (or a cool platform on the top the Nether Fortress) room where you have to fight a boss (Fire Dragon; Soul Dragon; Nether King; Abomination Of The Dead) and of course - new drops from him/her.

 

Thank you for reading the comments and please share, add or change something which I wrote. More people to think for a specific idea , thus more minds are focused for a great thing !

Fossils don't come from thin air. Also, grim reapers should be boss mobs that can transport souls to the nether. More temples should be made, and ghosts should replace ghasts. I already posted my suggestion under a few videos, people liked it i think (i got usually around 200-600 likes) and would love to hear what You think about it: how about making nether fortresses with "stages"? The closer to the center, the harder it gets. Something like:
"outskirts" stage would be poor and bland, just like the fortresses that we have right now.
The "near center" area would have some buildings and rooms, but with new mobs and better loot in the chests. Maybe it could look like someone actually lived here, just like in the Chocolate Quest mod castles (there's paintings, bookshelves, beds and things that would be in a normal Minecraft house).
And in the center of the fortress would be the sole, large castle (it would look the best in biomes like soulsand valley, because it would be an impressive sight if in open space, something like a massive castle with many side towers attached to it in a chaotic way) with different rooms and maybe a boss on the top. And maybe low chances of getting netherite scraps from chests. In my opinion Minecraft needs more endgame structures to make exploring the world more intresting and worth it. I hope You liked the idea :)

• A thought I've had for a while is to make the fortress more stronghold-esque, in the sense that it provides more endgame than just the wither. Perhaps incorporate something with the dragon egg so it provides a lengthier journey, whereas the current version can become bland to the average player following the defeat of the dragon and wither. As of now we have the 2 main bosses in the game being the Wither which is primarily fought in the overworld and the dragon which is the current endgame boss. But why stop there, why not have some sort of shrine in the fortress that you have to progress to after defeating the dragon and claiming the egg as your own? Perhaps even the long awaited addition of a baby dragon, and even the addition of a gauntlet to fight through, almost like the raid. but in a Colosseum, having the player fend off waves of nether enemies to protect the egg while it hatches. If you fail and the mobs destroy the egg, you lose the egg and have to go fight the dragon again to get a new one, if you complete it, a baby dragon as a pet.

     

    I've made rough designs for a Colosseum style to match with MinesCrafter02's design (size and color subject to change)

Lady Agnes and Cory said that they may redo Nether Fortress after 1.16 and now with all the requests for it, it is very possible that it will be updated. Crossings may be bigger in appearance and blaze spawner platforms could be more challenging and have a dungeon-ish look. The generation of the Fortress is also a problem as it most of the time is in weird location which makes it go through the area creating unaesthetic feel and bland look. It may also have vegetation growing on it as well as Crimson* or (Warped (if ever added)) bricks that could add more similarities to the environment that it is generated in. More loot and challenging areas with maybe some kind of lava or fire traps and holes in the bridges would make the Fortress so much more better visually with it's own mood and feel, also more dangerous and exciting to explore. This structure deserves justice.

Here are my general ideas on what kind of areas the New Nether Fortress will have.

  • Entrance- A stairwell leading up to the main bridge. Can be completely intact or partially broken
  • Main Bridge- A long bridge suspension that connects the entrance and the Grand Hall.
  • Grand Hall- Upgrading the Lava Well room into a larger room that connects the other structures via minor bridges

Dynamic Dungeons.

Dungeons would be more interesting if;

I - The dungeon was created as we advanced in it, unlike forts and abandoned mines (static structures). That is, a dungeon would be divided into parts, in which the next part will only be created when a condition of the previous part is satisfied.

II - The structure would be created from a pedestal. A sacrifice is offered to this pedestal (monster heads, choice in archeology pits, for example) and part 1 of the dungeon is created with another pedestal at its end.

III - Were found anywhere, but mainly underground.

IV - There were many different types: creatures, traps, lava pits, parkour and what you can imagine.

V - The composition of the structure of dungeons will depend on the biome to which they were found. For example: sandstone blocks, stone and its variants in desert biomes; prismarine bricks and their variants in ocean biomes; Nether bricks and their variants in nether biomes.

VI - added added new animations such as lying down and climbing on horizontal and vertical terrain.

VII - New exclusive mobs from these dungeons, mainly from the game "minecraft Dungeons". Being exclusive modified mobs, no descents.

VIII - If there were several rewards, including the restoration totem: The player's inventory is restored when spawning after a kill.

NOTE: make the spiders rotate; their base must be parallel to the surface on which they are supported.

I had the exact same idea with a different exceution!

There could be a telportation device. You can travel around the world and place one so you can come back to the spot. To not make this overpowered it could be either extremely difficult to find or would be really expensive (maybe using a new ore) and would have to be a late game item. The catch is that you have to have been there and place it. To travel you need at least two, one anchor and multiple others in places to travel to. These cannot be moved.

I would also like portals that connect two places in the same dimension. It would definately have an impact on how some servers operate, that's for sure. Nether railways would be a thing of the past though as there really wouldn't be a reason to take on that risk or expend those resources.

As such, maybe the portals should require materials that are far more difficult to find? For example, Diamond Blocks? It takes 9 diamonds to make one diamond block and if it followed the same rules in nether portal generation you would need a minimum of 10 diamond blocks - or 90 diamonds - to make a single teleporter. That level of expense would mean that people would still use rails for shorter range transportation and would save the diamonds for the long range transport.

Additionally, wouldn't this need some way of telling the portal which it's other half is? Unlike interdimensional portals, which generate on the other side, you'd need to tell it where it's other half is. So, maybe a craftable tool made from redstone that lets to "attune" two portals together? You use it on the first poral after it is built and activate it. It won't take you anywhere, but the portal will be lit. Then you go to the second portal, use it again, and it activates. The second portal would basically have been told the coordinates of the first portal by the device and, upon seeing a valid portal present, it makes the connection allowing you to travel between them.
